Posts.Content: Jul 5, 2008 05:00PM nycmom wrote: You might want to see a great book by an author Marc Silver I think is his name - the book was called Breast Cancer Husband  - words from other men who have been there. It wasn't yet written when my husband was my support person. Probalby it is available for under $1 on amazon by now. Good luck. Your description of the ups n downs does remind me of the roller coaster. You may have felt you were on the descent with new and not "favorable" info each time and may fear the descent will continue. As in roller coasters, it stops and then there is the climb/slog upward through chemo, ideally with fewer surprises and new news during that.

Posts.Content: Jul 5, 2008 07:50PM nycmom wrote: If I just wanted a second opinion on pathology slides, I would make sure I could get all the slides and then I would have Ira Bleiweiss, MD of Mount Sinai NY would read them.   I agree having one's slides seen is the least-invasive thing one can do. My slides were seen 3x before that- each institution's oncologist wanted her own pathologist to review. Not just a report from another place. In terms of surgeon, I naively perhaps thought all would suggest and perform the same procedure. I wanted it out, out out and went with the first one someone got me. It was August and a lot were on vacation. I think I tried for another and while, medically, one can wait a couple weeks, emotionally, I couldn't.
